bestBHT.bht: The words used by Jesus when referring to the dead girl highlight the transient nature of her death, as if she is in a short sleep. This comparison of death to sleep is a beautiful word that Jesus uses, emphasizing the expectation of a future resurrection. The hired mourners in the house are making a commotion, but Jesus dismisses them, showing that their ostentatious noise does not reflect genuine grief.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The damsel is not dead, but sleepeth—so brief her state of death as to be more like a short sleep.
The damsel is not dead, but sleepeth—so brief her state of death...
The damsel is not dead, but sleepeth—so brief her state of death as to be more like a short sleep.
John Calvin: Sleep is everywhere in Scripture employed to denote death; and there is no doubt but this comparison, taken from temporal rest, points out a future resurrection.
But here Christ expressly makes a distinction between sleep and death, so as to excite an expectation of life.
And yet this very circumstance was an additional confirmation of the miracle, that those persons entertained no doubt whatever as to her death.
Philip Schaff: The crowd was kept outside, three disciples accompanying Him.
He then speaks to the crowd inside, and after their scornful reply, they are put out of the house.
They are kept from entering into the chamber of death.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus undoubtedly meant that she was not dead to stay dead, though some hold that the child was not really dead.
It is a beautiful word (she is sleeping) that Jesus uses of death.
Jesus had dismissed one crowd, but finds the house occupied by the hired mourners making bedlam as if that showed grief with their ostentatious noise.
John Gill: Why make ye this ado and weep?...The damsel is not dead, but sleepeth."
Not but that she was truly dead, but not so as to remain under the power of death.
She was like a person in a sleep, who would in a little time be awaked out of it.

bhtAttempts.bht: The words used by Jesus when referring to the dead girl in Mark 5:39—The damsel is not dead, but sleepeth—highlight the transient nature of her death. It is as if she is in a short sleep, indicating that she is not meant to remain dead. This comparison of death to sleep is a beautiful word that Jesus uses, emphasizing the expectation of a future resurrection. The hired mourners in the house are making a commotion, but Jesus dismisses them, showing that their ostentatious noise does not reflect genuine grief.

The words used by Jesus when referring to the dead girl in this passage highlight the transient nature of her death. It is as if she is in a short sleep, indicating that she is not meant to remain dead. This comparison of death to sleep emphasizes the expectation of a future resurrection. The hired mourners in the house are making a commotion, but Jesus dismisses them, showing that their ostentatious noise does not reflect genuine grief.

Jesus refers to the deceased girl as sleeping, implying that her death is temporary. This comparison highlights the expectation of a future resurrection and emphasizes the transitory nature of her state. Despite the hired mourners making a commotion, Jesus dismisses them because their ostentatious noise does not reflect genuine grief.
